Oh God. Oh God. OH GOD. SAVE ME. They remastered it.

This may be the best game I've played in years. Strike that, this is the best game I've played in years. My background picture comes from this game. My facebook background picture comes from this game. I damaged my social relationships to a frankly alarming point by talking about this game to everyone I knew. I've skipped entire nights of sleep, just because I was too fascinated (my hands were literally shaking) by the approaching climax. I've let my beard grow wild and my eyes became those of a haunted doctor struggling against an invisible, inexorable enemy, just like the character I was playing. For weeks after completing it for the first time, I dreamt of mad bulls, of crows, of tunnels full of whispers in an alien tongue, of dark wells, of lies and treasons. Oh, the lies, the lies this game tells you.

But we'll get to that a bit later. First things first.



Pathologic is a 2006 russian game about an early XXth century small fictional town located in the middle of the russian steppe. A few days after the beginning of the game, the unnamed town is beset by a mysterious plague and everything starts falling into utter chaos. You are a healer and your goal is to discover the source of the plague and put an end to it.

You are given a choice between three characters : the Bachelor, man of logic and reason and professional doctor by trade ; the Haruspex, both learned in classical medicine and in the ancient local traditions of shamanism ; and the Changeling, a mysterious young vagrant girl who claims she can perform miracles. You have to complete the game as either the Haruspex or the Bachelor to be able to play as the Changeling (Devotress in the original version).


What you are reading is a review of the remastered version that came out on Steam on 29/10/2015, not to be confused with the remake of Pathologic, scheduled for November 2016. Aside from polished graphics, the main point of the remastered version is a way better english translation and a better voice acting. The original made quite some waves in Russia when it originally came out, but due to a very bad english translation and poor voice acting, wasn't very well-received abroad, and since it was the first game of the studio, they had very little at their disposal in terms of advertising. In any case, those problems are over now, thank Zeus, and Pathologic Classic HD is perfectly understandable and enjoyable"

Pathologic is a very ambitious, very unique, genre-bending, medium-defining video game which does things no other game has done before or since. As you arrive in town, the leader of the town, who had spread propaganda of his own immortality is found dead from a disease known as the sand plague". reviewText:
(I have completed a full playthrough of the original pathologic before its HD re-release. It was a personal favorite game of mine.)

Overview:

Pathologic's effectiveness as a survivial-horror game relies on the passage of time; gathering enough food and supplies for yourself is trying to begin with, and as the plague takes hold in the town, the price of food and medicine skyrockets as districts fill with plague vapors, rats, and the shambling sick. It's impossible not to feel the invisible noose of desperation tightening around your chosen character's neck.

As for the game's story, if you manage to keep yourself alive, you're going to uncover some wild stuff. The town this game is set in is steeped in cults, competing factions, and world-changing magic, but none of it is spelled out for you at the start. Magical Realism is a good way to describe it, which just can't be said about many games out there.

Each of the three player characters can learn things the other two can't. There are many unique NPC's to interact with and learn about the world from, and all of them treat each player character very differently. Many will tell half-truths and try and manipulate you to suit their ends.  There is branching dialogue and quests may resolve differently based on your actions.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Reasons you might love this game:

- A wonderfully original setting with interesting characters and lore.

- A sense of slow, creeping decay that many horror games aren't patient enough to pull off.

-A barter economy born of desperation: rummage through trash cans for baubles to trade children for, swap your only weapon for a loaf of bread, loot the houses of infected districts for items at the risk of contracting the Plague...you'll be making hard decisions constantly under time pressure.

- A strange but very well excecuted soundtrack.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Reasons you might not like this game:

-Combat is very clunky.

-You'll be doing a lot of walking from place to place with not much happening between besides trading with people or visiting a store. (Unless its a plague district or nighttime, when you can run into knife-weilding bandits.) There is no sprint button.

-If you don't like games with a lot of text. Characters have a lot to say.

- If you aren't careful, you can exhaust your supplies and money and be completely ruined well into the game. Keeping rolling saves / quicksaving often is highly reccomended.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------
All in all, if you are looking for an unrelenting, unique experience, this game is truly an unpolished gem that is well worth your time for its story and atmosphere alone.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Gameplay tips from someone who has played through the game:

- 'Q' brings up your quest log.  ' L' brings up letters you've received that will give you hints on what to do. They often show up at the start of a new day.   'P' brings up your status screen.

-If one of your Bound (Also called Adherents) dies at the end of a day, you didn't complete the day's main quest and will be locked out of all but one very grim ending to the game.

-Look through trash cans whenever you can.  Junk can be traded to children for invaluable supplies. Bottles can be filled up with water and traded to drunks for bandages and tornaquets.

-Equip clothing and use drugs that boost your immunity when going into infected districts/houses. It may be the difference between catching the Plague (which can only be cured through two very rare items) and remaining healthy. Take protective clothes off when you leave; they lose durability when being worn.

- Even with your best efforts, you're gonna probably gonna get the plague. The higher your infection bar, the faster your health will drain away.

reviewText:
Pathologic is a survival game about a town that's been affected by a seemingly incurable plague. You play as one of three characters: a charming bachelor doctor, a ritualistic healer, and a mysterious young girl with an unusual set of powers. Your enemy is invisible, but incredibly dangerous - and every day is a fight for survival.

It's a dark, haunting experience. And I absolutely adore it. Your choices have immediate and often far-reaching consequences. All of the quests are optional. Sometimes you won't even have time to complete quests if you need to find food or rest, but people are likely to die as a result of your decisions - even when you think you're doing the right thing.

This isn't the prettiest game by any stretch, but the world is fascinating. If you're concerned about the graphics not being up to par, there's not a whole lot to be concerned about. It's a game from 2005, sure, but the art, music, and overall design of this world are still captivating. And luckily all of the murals and posters have had their textures updated in this release. Plus, the added visual effects (depth of field and motion blur) do actually add to the mood considerably.

And that mood is phenomenal. Pathologic is a terrifying glimpse into a place that was crafted by a team determined to work towards creating a unified, hollistic vision. I've heard that the concept for this game came from a dream, and in playing this game, I certainly feel like I'm exploring one. It's a sometimes terrifying place, with weird citizens and strange cultures where you're never sure what's real - or who you can trust, for that matter.

I love this game. I love the people who made this game. It's fascinating. I can hardly stop thinking about it. It's like being a stranger in a strange land. I feel like I'm exploring Morrowind for the first time all over again, except it's brutal and tragic and I'm not the hero.

I can't recommend this game enough. It's rough around the edges, but it's fantastic. The new translation is also beyond my expectations. The original, for those who don't know, was often incomprehensible - but with the new one, you don't even need a map. I'm deighted Ice Pick Lodge decided to revisit a ten-year-old game and fix it up. This is the remastering this game deserved.

reviewText:
Pathologic was always a remarkable game. Tense, atmospheric, unforgiving, completely exhilarating. It captured the essence of player choice better than just about anything else - of reward versus cost, the now versus the potential future - in providing a constantly evolving world where everything you did always had to be measured against what you could have done instead.

None of that has changed in this newly translated version.

What has changed is that Pathologic is now also a truly impressive piece of comprehensible fiction. Carrying forth the great Russian literary tradition into a new medium with an intricate web of a story that tackles subjects such as state, religion, addiction, mortality, family, mysticism, ethics, murder, clinical research and individual ideology and ambition. All told through monomaniacal character dialogue and the stark scenery of the world.

It's a story and world building that works on many simultaneous levels, and the things it has to say about both the human condition and the video game medium itself - and by extension, art in general - is deeper and more poignant than anything I've witnessed before in video games.

It all adds up to an extraordinary experience, and also one of the very best games I have ever played.

reviewText:
Plus: Strong literary narrative, atmospheric, immersive, creative, and impactful; a place and story to get invested in and a unique gaming experience
Minus: lacks technical wow, strains patience at times
Interesting:
-unforgiving resource management is opaque on first playthrough which may frustrate some and appeal to others, but in both cases contributes to a sense of triumph.
-mature content and themes; some may find it discomforting
-a novels worth of exposition in dialogue text. It's not in the original language, but a sense of narrative mastery and expression came through even in the broken translation. This translation will be its own beast.
-a purist might recommend the original in all its messy glory. Where else will you here a voice actor botch their line, pause, and start again? Or read Dankovsky joking about getting to heaven by means of dry peas?
-if you like it, there's a comprehensive remake underway, and similar, excellent, game by the same developers (The Void)
Coming at this game having playing the Original, I only have an eye towards this new translation and how it colours the narrative. While the vague expressions and broken phrasing of the original translation added somewhat to surreality of the experience, there was oodles lost in translation and a more distinct yet somewhat inaccessible actual mystery. The dated visuals punched well above their weight in creating gloomy town ambience, and mainly came to the fore with globby face models that could frown but otherwise had trouble being expressive; updates here are welcome but uncritical. Stability, bugs and quest flag curios are probably the best cause for a HD revamp, and to my knowledge this area has been improved.
A dissonant, beautiful game, its premise finds a superstitious, stratified, rural-industrial town experiencing the death of an elder figurehead, inciting suspicion in several parties. Three outsiders will be drawn into this precipice of unfolding events and the possibility of a dangerous disease being responsible, and players take the role of one of these outsiders; 'healers' in the guise of a methodical doctor, a shamanistic surgeon, and a blessed urchin.
While each of these characters will navigate the same town, and meet (predominantly) the same cast of characters, they will be following their own narrative path and will have a different series of objectives and interactions than each other. Its atmospheric qualities lay heavy; bleak, surreal, and insular. The queer provincial locality and absurdities that no one blinks an eye at contribute a Lynchian quality - each of the 'healers' is very much a stranger in a strange land, mistrusted and beguiled by agendas at every turn. A great soundscape with mostly ambient synth variants is a strong point contributing to the overall powerful and memorable experience.
At its core it is a first person resource management adventure. To speak first to the mechanics; it's structured as an FPS, and combat, while prevalent, is only the focus of a few notable sequences. In many cases fighting, and weaponry, are a resource related calculable risk, and players find serviceable shooter mechanics that likely still feel awkward and lack punch. The game takes place over twelve days, with each in game day comprising of two real-time hours. Beyond reloading saves and the time-freeze during character dialogue, each playthrough has a fixed playtime.
Over time, you'll come to know the twists and turns of the town intimately. The shortcuts (which you’ll memorize as time is always ticking), the pub by the water barrel, the left turn at the rickety fence to get to Anna's place from Eve's.  It's a great way to evoke a sense of place, a big factor in the isolated, fictional steppe town. Walking is painfully slow across the large town and a key experience; equal parts introspective, off-puttingly slow, and eventually as the town becomes more dangerous, a prospect of apprehension, your travel across the town between bouts of exposition is pervasive.
More commonly in the game you'll be managing several pools of resources; fatigue, health, money, food, level of infection, medicine (for health and infection), reputation, time and later in the game as the stakes get higher, the lives of other significant characters. If that sounds like a hot mess, that’s because it is. These resources are strongly intertwined; sleeping reduces fatigue and increases health (more so with medicine, but that increases fatigue so you'll need to sleep more), but uses time, which increases hunger, infection, and runs out the deadline on tasks. Bandages and tourniquets can heal health instantly, but cost money, which you'll need to spend on food to keep your hunger down, and methods of reducing infection often damage health and cost money. Daily tasked are failed at midnight, and traversing the town is a lengthy amble.
This system is fairly punishing, especially when you're walking in blind, and can snowball such that you dig yourself into a situation of guaranteed failure where the last viable save is in the distant past, before the snowball started rolling. Looting and fighting wandering vagrants present a risk/reward scenario that can yield value like money or trade goods at the risk of getting hurt or killed. Robbing and killing citizens, as well as some story decisions, might hit your reputation, which can make it harder for you to shop or navigate town, perhaps necessitating continuing brutality. Notably, the different healers have different levels of ease handling reputation; the closest thing to a difficulty setting available. Other items and trinkets create several sub-economies, such as the nuts-and-razors for medicine of the town’s children, or the water for bandages of the parched drunkards, which can be managed by looting, scavenging and trade as well. It's overall very rich and you'll never find yourself without something to do; quite the reverse.
But beyond how punishing and legitimately frustrating it can be, it is perfectly entrenched to cause investment and tension within the player, and eliciting emotional engagement is one of the games strong points. A sense of achievement at having suffered through another day is tempered by the updated body count, the latest development of a town in crisis, and the overall nihilistic Russianness.
A portion has to be stated about the literary quality of the narrative. High-handed in places, gritty and verisimilitudinous in others, it overall is a little niche, and does not exactly appeal to a broad range of potential users. It cannot woo anyone with accessible gameplay; it melds its play experience between genres and through a commitment to storytelling, so players will have to be open to several classically disparate things. Awaiting though is a text cognizant of Brecht, Camus and Dostoevsky, easy names to sling around but well-earned here. It's also, as a text, very concerned with the player experience and engagement, and the overall conceit here goes to some novel and delightful places, but also hurtles towards a legitimate and intense amalgamation of themes, conceptual content that the player can take out of the satisfying and comprehensive ending; no deflated wrap-ups or truncated copouts.
Psychological horror, tension, threatening imagery and oppressive bleakness contribute to an intrusive sense of disquiet and disturbance. With some broader exceptions like plague victims and districts, Pathologic rarely employs traditional slash horror content like monsters and jump scares. Artfully setting the tone with a mock funeral intro, genre horror will be endemic to your experience for the rest of the game.
A certain openness, and sometimes patience, is required, but for those inclined an almost incomparable, human, and weirdly triumphant experience is available. Here's to the rich and morbid treasure that Ice Pick Lodge began with.

reviewText:
Pathologic is a beautifully dark, poetic game. It will make your skin crawl, give you nightmares, leave you in awe, and remain in your thoughts for days on end. The music is fantastically creepy and catchy all at once. I found myself grunting along almost immediately, despite not knowing the words (assuming those ARE words…?). The facial expressions of certain characters might make you pee in your pants a little. It’s ok. Just let it happen. Immerse yourself.

*** I cannot recommend Pathologic highly enough, but ONLY to those who would be predisposed to enjoying it. Every negative review I’ve read thus far was written by someone who was doomed not to like the game in the first place. The following are my notes on this phenomenon. It just isn’t a game for everyone. I’ve also included some random thoughts that aren’t super important or thrilling. I just wanted to throw ‘em in there, because it’s 4 AM and I’m the reigning queen of this review. ***

NOTE: THERE IS NOTHING SHAMEFUL ABOUT DISLIKING TEXT-HEAVY GAMES. I've met many avid bookworms who hate reading too much in-game. It’s ok! But don’t flippin' blame the writers/devs when you die at the end of the first day and can’t figure out why. If you hadn’t been skimming, you’d know. Negative reviewers: I’m shaking my head at a handful of you. I'm glad you weren't seeking my approval to begin with, because it would not have been granted. Untz.

Pathologic is more eery than scary. There are a few jump-scares, but not many. The majority of what makes this game marinate in your mind for hours after playing is the creepy, indirect way it leads you through its story. Don’t expect an action-packed thriller. The pacing is slow and deliberate, especially when compared to most modern games.

YOU WON’T UNDERSTAND EVERYTHING PEOPLE ARE SAYING FROM THE GET-GO. THAT DOESN’T MEAN THE TRANSLATION IS BAD. Most of the text is brimming with similes and riddles galore. That’s intentional, as shown by the fact that many of your own dialogue options will be variations on the “IDK WTF U SED, M8” theme. After playing for a few days, you’ll start to retroactively de-muddle some of it. From what I’ve heard, those who've played all three characters’ stories enjoyed going back and finally understanding the obscure bits. Don’t stress it! Let the metaphors flow over you. Just don’t forget that within that flow are chunks of important information. It’s not hard to tell the difference – smooth vs. chunky – but some people can’t handle it. Know yourself before agonizing over this.

Nipples. The more you notice them, the more you’ll… notice them. Nips on ♥♥♥♥. Giggles and ♥♥♥♥♥. Traffic cones. Party hats. Front-buttons. Nips.

Whomever translated this version deserves a lot of credit. Don't get me wrong, there are quite a few little grammatical issues and misspellings, but the phrasings themselves are absolutely poetic. How about this spoiler-free gem? “There were other signs, too. Frightening scribblings and repulsive oily spots on walls here and there. Raspy breathing that could only belong to giant lungs can be heard by the silent houses. They say the shabnak, the embodiment of the disease, is breathing poisonous air, leaving her fat on the walls as she walks by.” Whaaaaaaaaat? Yes. What? Yessssssss. I love it.

This game isn’t called Everquest. There is another game that goes by that name.

In a similar vein, the quests don’t last forever. They also don’t spur multiple additional quests, bleeding out into impossibly huge task trees. Each day is compartmentalized: you get a few quests, try to complete them, and know that they will disappear the next day. Use your best judgment re: route optimization while traipsing around town, and you shouldn’t have much trouble completing everything in time. You’ll usually have an extra hour or two to go rob some innocents, maybe kill a couple of bad guys, and stare at some cool-looking wall paintings, some of which feature the aforementioned prominent nips.

To echo everyone else: you’ll be rummaging in the trash a lot, hoping to find some sharp, dirty objects. These can be traded to children for drugs and bullets. Kids are the best. Also, don’t waste your water by drinking it. Water and vegetables are worthless for consumption, as in real life. Eat bread and fatty meat; they will keep you going for a long time. Trust me. I’m a bacheloctor. I know things.
I've still only scratched the surface of this game, but it has left a deep, emotional impact on me that will probably never go away. 9/10.

Can’t wait for the remake. Hoping for a loot all" key and a slightly more fluid equipment/items system."

reviewText:
[based on the older version]

Pathologic is my favorite game of all time. It is a critically acclaimed game from Russian Developer Ice Pick Lodge, who also made The Void and Knock Knock. It has absolutely everything I want in a game, it is dark, bleak and violent, but also beautiful and intelligent. The story is mysterious and fascinating, full of twists and turns. It is an open world, survival horror, RPG adventure FPS, set in a strange and wonderful town. The game wants to kill you, not only that, it wants to destroy your save files, make all of them unusable. The game tracks a variety of player data, Reputation, Health, Immunity, Hunger, Exhaustion, and Infection. If your reputation is too low you will be attacked on sight by the townsfolk, you lose reputation by killing innocent people, you gain it by doing good deeds and killing criminals. If your health is too low, you die, obviously, however, gaining health is not always an easy thing, even a small fight can put you in a dangerous situation. The only way to heal is with bandages and tourniquets which you get by trading bottles of water with drunks. You get water by taking bottles out of garbage cans and filling them with water. Immunity determines your ability to fight plague. Hunger is a constant enemy, as the situation deteriorates, the economy changes, a loaf of bread may cost 4 times as much on the second day, and if you run out of food, it begins to eat away at your health until you die. You can buy food at stores or break into people's houses and wreck up the place, stealing all of their food in the process. Exhaustion is your tiredness, like a normal person you need to sleep at night, if your exhaustion is too high, you can die. Maybe you need to sleep, but if you sleep, you'll starve. And infection determines the effects of the virus taking over your body. If you savescum you can avoid getting infected for a while, but certain story segments may force you to. Infection can be treated with medicine, and cured with a children's powder, a rare and important item which can save you in a pinch. At night the knifebums run free, stabbing people to death and rifling through their pockets, and you as well if you're not careful. As the game progresses, the town is slowly devoured by plague, and each day is worse than the last.

But hiding among all this evil and punishing behavior, is one of the most beautiful and amazing stories ever told in a game. It came to them in a dream. The characters are spectacular, it has branching paths and meaningful dialogue options. It is filled with warring factions and groups, all plotting against each other, your friend today can be your enemy tomorrow. In Russia, this game won awards for it's storytelling, but their earlier release suffered from a terrible translation. I didn't think it was that bad, I felt the translation made the town seem more foreign, it was still an amazing game, but we can finally enjoy the game as it was meant to be played. This is a much better translation that makes a lot more sense. There are 3 playable characters totalling 70+ hours of gameplay. In the earlier version the Devotress's path was unplayable due to the state of it's translation, but this time they used an in house team to make sure they got it right, and now her path is fully playable. You unlock her by completing the path of one of the other players, she's the woman as reward.

The only caveat I would add is that I actually prefered the opening scene in the theater from the original version. I felt it had more emotion, and better acting, but the new version is defintely clearer, and probably a lot closer to the original Russian.

Each character's path is different. When you choose one character the others plot against you. The bachelor walks into town a celebrated hero and immediately begins mingling with the town's ruling elite. The haruspex shows up and is immediately beaten to a pulp and wanted dead by the entire town, he is starving and tired, and the only mission he can initially find is a hit job against a small child. In the original release this mission was changed to have you murder a dwarf. It made no sense but they did it because they were afraid, but in this release they returned this mission to it's previous condition. And after pulling out a gun and shooting a random child on the street just to see if it was possible, I can assure you that this game has been restored to it's original Russian state. It is actually a pretty damn bold decision in the current climate. I don't know about the devotress's path because I didn't complete the game yet to unlock her, but I suspect it is the most interesting part.

When you begin the game you are given a list of adherents, each character has their own adherents. If you fail to complete your missions during the day one of your adherents will get sick, and they will die if you do not provide them with a children's powder. In order to see the ending of the game, at least one of your adherants has to be alive at the end, and you can save before it to see the different endings each adherant has to offer. Some are incompatible, for one to live, the other must die. Although I have not seen the ending yet.

The graphics are a little nicer, and everything has been polished to perfection. The music, incidentally, is heavenly. Even the console mode is baked into the game and looks a lot prettier. The number one criticism of the previous version was it's translation, well that is gone now. Hopefully people can finally enjoy the game as it was meant to be. It really is one of the hidden gems on Steam, it is probably the most underrated game in all of history. It is so good, it is actually important, it gives us a glimpse of what games could be like some day. It is an artistic masterpiece which I have enjoyed more than any movie, book, tv show or music I have ever encountered. It is glorious, on par with the great works of literature, and you owe it to yourself to try it out. This is by far the best version of this game and a nice warm up to the full on remake in 2016. I'm hyped.

reviewText:
Fair warning: This game is not for everyone.

Pathologic is hard to describe. It is part survival, part exploration, part role-playing, and part first person shooter. The story is confusing, intentionally so, and the game does not hold you by the hand. You are expected to pay attention, learn the lore and story behind the events taking place, and generally invest into the experience. If you do that, you will find no other experience like it. Your choices will matter. If you just want a casual learning curve, skip right on to something else because Pathologic is not for you.

The gameplay is clunky, old school, and the graphics are very basic for a game re-released in 2015. But as you play Pathologic, you will figure out the inner workings of the game just as you explore the innards of the town, quickly find what best to do and not to do, and generally get over the mechanical hurdles. If you want a quick start tip: buy food on day 1, stock up as much as you can, because prices skyrocket on day 2. Check the trash bins and learn to trade. Trading with the townsfolk is probably the best way to acquire wealth in items, especially bullets.

You will be walking from place to place a lot, and it is important to learn the layout of the town and how to best hit your objectives. This is something you will do over the course of the game, so it's entirely okay to look at your map to find proper placement. Do note that time does not pass while you are looking at the map, letters, or quests. But time does pass otherwise, and any quests not finished by midnight are dropped.

If you are still curious just what is going on in that town by the river, give it a shot. Play the Bachelor first, as it's a good introduction to the game. The first few days are slow, but once you are past that things quickly pick up. If you want hard mode, where you are dropped from orbit, battered, and then left unconscious in hostile territory, play Haruspex. Do note that Haruspex basically assumes you are familiar with most of the mechanics, people, and methods of survival. I highly recommend doing a Bachelor run first, and that should be anywhere from 20 to 30+ hours.

Note: There is a re-release of Pathologic on the way; if you enjoyed the HD release, throw them some cash for those stretch goals. Or just wait for that game to hit instead of playing the HD release.

The game requires quite a few hours of experimentation which can be easy if you quick save and quick load often; just be ready to sacrifice your sanity as you attempt to balance drug taking with disease, starvation and exhaustion all while selling your gun to get a can of peas so you can live another day. If you are unable to spend the time to learn the game and it's strange and nerve wrecking mechanics you might want to skip it altogether, but you're not a coward are you?

reviewText:
Pathologic is a lot like a dream in many respects - appropriate, given how I hear it was based on one. Like a dream, it is difficult to describe, and to tell you truly I have significant difficulty recounting the events of the game's story: I can describe them adequately at an entirely superficial level, but bereft of their context their precise meaning is impossible to communicate plainly. In that sense, Pathologic is what I always point to when the question arises of whether video games can be considered art - it bears little similarity in terms of its structure to a film or novel, but instead makes innovative use of the unique characteristic of the medium to tell a story that cannot really exist in any other format.

On the basic level, Pathologic is a game where you amble about at a leisurely pace between various buildings. Sometimes you shoot and cut people, and you'll likely spend a lot of time scrounging for garbage to barter with and the necessities of life. It is slow, sometimes to the point of tedium, sometimes ugly, and curiously uninviting, even foreboding. It is also an incredibly atmospheric, richly layered narrative experience - something that exists not by itself but rather in the process of interaction between the game and the player.

I'd say it's like nothing else in the world - a one-of-a-kind journey. Opening it up just now felt like coming back home for the first time in a very long while.

It's one of the best survival-focused games I've ever seen, and after all these years nothing comes to mind that has surpassed it. Time flows in real time in the game, important characters can live or die based on how you spend that time, and events happen whether you're there to see them or not. On the first day you may casually introduce yourself to the important members of the city, only to find yourself trading your gun to a child for a loaf of bread or some pills within a few days because of the rising prices of the shops. Pathologic is an extremely dreary game, and it's that dreariness that made it so famous.

The other thing that made the game famous, or rather infamous, was its translation, which was fairly bad, particularly in the third storyline that you unlock by playing at least one of the others. But now, at long last, we have a new fully retranslated version of the story, complete with newly recorded audio. Some of the new voice acting is still pretty bad, but it's not like it could really get much worse from the original, and most of the dialogue is text-based anyways.

Other than that, not much has changed. The graphics have been touched up, but it's mostly just an addition of bloom and SSAO to give the buildings a slightly different look. The big difference is just the widescreen support, really. The gameplay is the same Pathologic as ever, and I'm perfectly okay with that.

Overall, for $13 I'd highly recommend trying Pathologic at some point. It's a very strange game and it's easy to get turned off within the first few minutes by the strange opening scenes, but once you get into it it's hard to get out of it. It may not be the fully remade edition that's releasing next year (and you might even want to wait for that instead, if a true remake feels more like something you'd rather wait on), but I'm just happy to finally own Pathologic on Steam in a form that I can actually read.

reviewText:
Сама игра это большое театраное представление и на сцене — три фигуры. Жертвы обстоятельств, как часто бывает. Судьба приготовила им нелегкое испытание: ближайшие 12 дней будут настоящим кошмаром, своеобразной борьбой за жизнь, в заражонном городе. Спастись самим, а так же вытащить из капкана добрую половину населения, заодно навсегда поставив крест на заразе, охватившей город.
Захватывающая история — ценнейший компонент «Мора». Ложь, предательство, интриги, неожиданные доброжелатели… Витки событий следуют один за другим. Так, крупные правящие семейства — Каины, Ольгимские и Сабуровы, растащившие во владение отдельные участки города, — все время пытаются подмять нас под себя. «Не верьте соседям» — напутствует отпрыск погибшего властителя. Странно, но «соседи» столь же убедительно твердят о его нечистоплотности. А с приездом Инквизитора накопленные сведения вообще отправляются на свалку. Здесь никому нельзя верить!
Диалоги потрясают насыщенностью. В меру литературный текст иногда достигает огромных размеров, превращая приключение в некий аналог интерактивной книги. «Интерактивной» — потому что для большинства реплик предусмотрено несколько ответов, причем разные варианты зачастую по-разному влияют на дальнейший ход дискуссии, а то и всей игры. Ну, а «книги» — в силу отсутствия озвучки.
И да чуть не забыл! Давящая, депрессивная обстановка сразу   приходит от прогулки по зараженному кварталу, мимо покрытых плесенью «плачущих» домов, ядовитых испарений и зомби, закутанных в грязные простыни, становится не по себе.
Несмотря на то, что развернуться здесь почти негде, побегать предстоит от души. Без карты и навыков владения ею соваться в жуткий лабиринт из петляющих улочек, ветхих построек и непреодолимых препятствий (заборы, ограды и всякий мусор) опасно. А чтобы игрок не заплутал в хитросплетениях сюжета, авторы выдали ему специальный блокнотик, где отмечаются основные и дополнительные задачи (подобных квестов редко бывает более трех штук, их скрупулезное выполнение не входит в раздел обязательств, но попотеть, тем не менее, придется). Имейте в виду: не успеете до полуночи проставить галочки рядом со всеми пунктами — ровно в двенадцать страницы дневника опустеют, незаконченные дела так ими и останутся.
Всем приятной игры, выбирайте правельные решения.

reviewText:
I gave this a fair shot. I really tried to enjoy this game, I really wanted to. But the translation, horrible voice acting and lack of direction makes me wish I never paid for this even at 90% off.

The game is focussed around lots of reading. This would be fine if the translation was decent. The translation is so bad a fan tried to make his own to replace it but since then I heard he gave up. If the games' dialogue wasn't very important to the game I'd keep playing but you have to read to know where to go, what to look for on the map and more.

I do like the reputation system and the general premise and atmosphere in the game. It's like a mix of Majora's Mask and Deus Ex. Perhaps with a later update this will be worth trying out again. But as far as right now, why would I put in hours into this game when there's plenty of others calling for me.

Now for the ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
A town in the middle of nowhere. A festering and unstoppable plague. Food, water, and medication running low. Twelve days to find a cure.

A slow walk through the Steppe will leave you with more questions than answers. The empty expressions of the local inhabitants, almost fully aware of their impending doom. The sounds of people- no wait- children, laughing in the distance. The large, glass obelisk blocking out the sky near the river at the edge of town. The dread filled streets are almost too much to bear, they make you forget that you haven’t eaten since you left the capital. The sun is going down. You only have one stale cracker and two mismatched bullets at the bottom of your empty pocket. End of day one.

The clock is ticking, Bachelor.

Tomorrow, the first man dies of the pestilence.
